name: 2-methylbicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien-7-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2579

name: 2-methylbicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien-7-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2579
Reason: The target compound is 2-methylbicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien-7-one. To predict its melting point, we consider the functional groups present. Starting with the bicyclic octa-1,3,5-triene system, this structure often has a higher melting point due to the rigidity of the fused ring system which restricts molecular motion. This rigidity may contribute approximately +20°C to the melting point compared to a similar acyclic structure. The keto group (C=O) generally increases melting points due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipoles but in this case, it is part of a conjugated system which may make this effect less pronounced, therefore we can estimate an increase of about +40°C. The methyl group attached to the cycloaliphatic ring system generally contributes a relatively small increase to the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, perhaps around +5°C. However, since the compound's overall steric bulk reduces its ability to pack efficiently in the solid state, this could actually lower the melting point, so the net effect of the methyl group could be closer to 0°C in this context. Without the contributions of other functional groups and considering the overall structure, the base molecule for comparison could be benzene, with a melting point of 5.5°C.
